dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey B, so, you know, we've been keeping an eye on Lilium, the German aerospace company, right? Those folks with the air taxis?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey B, so, you know, we've been keeping an eye on Lilium, the German aerospace company, right? Those folks with the air taxis?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, the ones that, uh, promise to beat traffic and fly us around in electric jets. What's the latest? Another delay?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, the ones that, uh, promise to beat traffic and fly us around in electric jets. What's the latest? Another delay?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. So, they've officially delayed the release of their new seven-seat air taxi. And, um, despite initial plans for a reverse-merger with Qell, they're still going that route, but at a significantly reduced valuation. Like, down to $3.3 billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. So, they've officially delayed the release of their new seven-seat air taxi. And, um, despite initial plans for a reverse-merger with Qell, they're still going that route, but at a significantly reduced valuation. Like, down to three point three billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today's announcement brings us closer to launching our passenger service, said Daniel Wiegand, co-founder and CEO, Lilium in a statement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa, $3.3 billion? I mean, they're kinda known for some, uh, failed attempts in the past, right? So this isn't exactly a shock, but that's a big hit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa, three point three billion dollars? I mean, they're kinda known for some, uh, failed attempts in the past, right? So this isn't exactly a shock, but that's a big hit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, big hit. And get this, they're actually refunding like $830 million through this deal. What's wild is they've essentially abandoned their original aim to beat traffic on congested city roads. They're struggling to prove these small electric aircraft are even viable, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, big hit. And get this, they're actually refunding like eight hundred thirty million dollars through this deal. What's wild is they've essentially abandoned their original aim to beat traffic on congested city roads. They're struggling to prove these small electric aircraft are even viable, apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Munich-based startup will raise $830 million through the deal with $380 million from Engles SPAC, and $450 million in private investments in public equity to fuel its bet small electric aircraft can beat the traffic on congested city roads.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, so they're refunding money, *and* abandoning their core mission, but then I saw something about them saying commercial operations are being brought forward to 2022? Like, two years ahead of schedule? [interrupts] How does that even make sense when they're delaying the new plane?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, so they're refunding money, and abandoning their core mission, but then I saw something about them saying commercial operations are being brought forward to twenty twenty two? Like, two years ahead of schedule? How does that even make sense when they're delaying the new plane?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lilium said the funds would be used to fund the development and testing of a new seven seat electric aircraft and the launch of commercial operations in 2024.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's the kicker. Lilium specifically said those funds *won't* be used for the development and testing of a *new* seven-seat aircraft. The CEO, Daniel Wiegand, even stated that today's announcement 'brings us further away from launching our passenger service.' He admitted they're abandoning their unique electric jet technology because it's not the key to higher capacity or lower cost.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's the kicker. Lilium specifically said those funds won't be used for the development and testing of a new seven-seat aircraft. The C E O, Daniel Wiegand, even stated that today's announcement brings us further away from launching our passenger service. He admitted they're abandoning their unique electric jet technology because it's not the key to higher capacity or lower cost.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lilium said the funds would be used to fund the development and testing of a new seven seat electric aircraft and the launch of commercial operations in 2024. Today's announcement brings us closer to launching our passenger service, said Daniel Wiegand, co-founder and CEO, Lilium in a statement. We are pursuing our unique electric jet technology because it is the key to higher-capacity aircraft, with lower cost per seat mile while delivering low noise and low emissions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so it sounds like the whole dream of personal air taxis, or at least the battery-powered ones, might be, um, cooling off a bit? This isn't just a Lilium problem, is it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so it sounds like the whole dream of personal air taxis, or at least the battery-powered ones, might be, um, cooling off a bit? This isn't just a Lilium problem, is it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely not just them. I mean, it's a clear indication that the race among aviation startups is cooling. You look at Joby, though, they actually closed a reverse merger recently, valued at $6.6 billion, [overlap] but they were already public.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely not just them. I mean, it's a clear indication that the race among aviation startups is cooling. You look at Joby, though, they actually closed a reverse merger recently, valued at six point six billion dollars, but they were already public.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Liliums move to raise capital via a reverse-merger is the latest signal that the race among aviation startups to launch a battery-powered air taxi is heating up. Joby raised $1.6 billion in its own reverse merger with a blank-check company in February that valued the California-based business at $6.6 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlap] Yeah, Joby's a different beast. But then you have Lilium's German rival, Volocopter, who just lost $239 million from investors like BlackRock because they couldn't secure adequate funding. It's a tough market out there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Joby's a different beast. But then you have Lilium's German rival, Volocopter, who just lost two hundred thirty nine million dollars from investors like BlackRock because they couldn't secure adequate funding. It's a tough market out there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Liliums German rival Volocopter also raised $239 million from investors including BlackRock earlier this month, according to Reuters.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And Lilium itself, uh, they lost their place in Europe's unicorn club after a $1 billion valuation, and then a measly $35 million round from Baillie Gifford. Not exactly inspiring confidence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And Lilium itself, uh, they lost their place in Europe's unicorn club after a one billion dollar valuation, and then a measly thirty five million dollar round from Baillie Gifford. Not exactly inspiring confidence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lilium itself joined Europes unicorn club of startups with a $1 billion valuation following a $35 million round from high-profile tech investors Baillie Gifford in June.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And didn't they also, like, scrap plans for that whole network of vertiports in Florida? With Ferrovial, the Heathrow airport owners? That's a pretty big sign they're scaling back.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And didn't they also, like, scrap plans for that whole network of vertiports in Florida? With Ferrovial, the Heathrow airport owners? That's a pretty big sign they're scaling back.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lilium announced plans in January to develop a network of vertiports across Florida with Spanish infrastructure company Ferrovial, which is the owner of Londons Heathrow Airport...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, cancelled that back in January. And no talks for anything similar in Europe either. It's all just, um, a bit of a mess for what was supposed to be the future of travel.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, cancelled that back in January. And no talks for anything similar in Europe either. It's all just, um, a bit of a mess for what was supposed to be the future of travel.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lilium announced plans in January to develop a network of vertiports across Florida with Spanish infrastructure company Ferrovial... and revealed today that it was in talks for a similar network of shuttle landing pads in Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, in short, the future of flying cars might be a little further away than we thought, especially if you're betting on Lilium's current trajectory. It sounds like they're just trying to, like, stay afloat rather than revolutionize transport right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, in short, the future of flying cars might be a little further away than we thought, especially if you're betting on Lilium's current trajectory. It sounds like they're just trying to, like, stay afloat rather than revolutionize transport right now.
